prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HERGE_RA0h
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum observations of 2 HzRGs. CO(4-3) at 219.32 GHz for MRC0037-258 and CO(5-4) at 239.15 GHz in MRC0114-211.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We require a continuum sensitivity of 75 µJy, integrated over all 4 basebands. This sets our required integration time. The tunings are set such that we cover the redshifted CO lines at the edges of BB1 and BB4 in either target. In order to spectrally resolve these CO lines, we use FDM with spectral averaging of 8 rather than TDM. This has almost no effect on the data rates, but allows twice better spectral resolution.
The spatial resolution we require is <0.3". This can be provided by any of the C34-5, C34-6 or C34-7 configurations. As the individual source components are expected to be compact, and the total source size smaller than a few arcseconds, there is no danger that the source would be over-resolved in any of these configurations.
The overheads are large as these low-density targets cannot be grouped more.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HERGE_RA1h
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Continuum observations of 3 HzRGs. CO(6-5) at 236.86 GHz for MRC0152-209 and CO(5-4) at 250.59 GHz in MRC0211-256. No lines in MRC0156-252.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We require a continuum sensitivity of 75 µJy, integrated over all 4 basebands. This sets our required integration time. The tunings are set such that we cover the redshifted CO lines in BB1 and BB3 in two of the sources. In order to spectrally resolve these CO lines, we use FDM with spectral averaging of 8 rather than TDM. This has almost no effect on the data rates, but allows twice better spectral resolution.
The spatial resolution we require is <0.3". This can be provided by any of the C34-5, C34-6 or C34-7 configurations. As the individual source components are expected to be compact, and the total source size smaller than a few arcseconds, there is no danger that the source would be over-resolved in any of these configurations.
The overheads are large as these low-density targets cannot be grouped more.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HERGE_RA3h

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We require a continuum sensitivity of 75 µJy, integrated over all 4 basebands. This sets our required integration time. The tunings are set such that we cover the redshifted CO lines in BB1, BB2 and BB3 in all 3 sources. In order to spectrally resolve these CO lines, we use FDM with spectral averaging of 8 rather than TDM. This has almost no effect on the data rates, but allows twice better spectral resolution.
The spatial resolution we require is <0.3". This can be provided by any of the C34-5, C34-6 or C34-7 configurations. As the individual source components are expected to be compact, and the total source size smaller than a few arcseconds, there is no danger that the source would be over-resolved in any of these configurations.
The overheads are large as these low-density targets cannot be grouped more.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:

The spatial resolution we require is <0.3". This can be provided by any of the C34-5, C34-6 or C34-7 configurations. As the individual source components are expected to be compact, and the total source size smaller than a few arcseconds, there is no danger that the source would be over-resolved in any of these configurations.
The overheads are large as these low-density targets cannot be grouped more.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Using Spitzer, Herschel, SCUBA and LABOCA, we have obtained 12-band 3.6 to 870µm photometry of 71 radio galaxies covering 1<z<5.2, accurately defining their SEDs, their stellar masses of 1-5x10^11 Msun, and enabling us to disentangle the starburst and AGN components. For the handful of high-redshift radio galaxies (HzRGs) with arcsecond-resolution imaging of the dust and CO emission, we find surprisingly complex morphologies, suggesting that in these objects, gas-rich major mergers rather than continuous gas accretion may be dominant. Here, we propose to test this hypothesis by complementing the existing low resolution data with 0.3" spatial resolution ALMA imaging. Such data are essential to determine whether the FIR emission seen by Herschel is associated with the AGN host, or an interacting companion galaxy that is triggering the starburst/AGN, or some combination of these. This will be the first systematic study of the dust distribution at a few kpc scales in a representative sample of 19 HzRGs. Compared to observations obtained to date, we will quadruple the existing sample, to an order of magnitude lower noise level, and with 5x better spatial resolution.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Earth and Space Sciences, Chalmers University of Technology
Royal Observatory, Edinburgh, Science and Technology Facilities Council
Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL), California Institute of Technology
Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen
